title: Phonikud: Hebrew Grapheme-to-Phoneme Conversion for Real-Time Text-to-Speech
author: Amit Roth (Hebrew University of Jerusalem), Arnon Turetzky (Bar-Ilan University), Ella Zeldes (Bar-Ilan University), Guy Mor-Lan (Bar-Ilan University), ..., Yael Segal (Hebrew University of Jerusalem)
relevance_why: The G2P conversion method proposed can enhance text-to-speech systems, which are directly applicable to Haohe Liu's research in audio generation and restoration, particularly in generating intelligible speech from text inputs.
background: This paper addresses the challenge of converting unvocalized Hebrew text into phonemically detailed representations for efficient text-to-speech synthesis.
contribution: Phonikud introduces an enhanced diacritization method for Hebrew text to accurately predict phonetic features like stress, achieving improved real-time Hebrew text-to-speech performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing models struggled with the ambiguity of Hebrew phonetic features, requiring larger architectures that were slow and inefficient for real-time applications.
technical_comparison.novelty: Phonikud enhances a state-of-the-art diacritization model with lightweight prediction heads for stress and shva realization, resulting in accurate G2P conversion while maintaining small model size.

key_innovation: The combination of enhanced vowel diacritization with additional phonetic symbols allows for precise transcription of Hebrew text into IPA, enabling efficient real-time TTS.
real_world_impact: This work significantly enhances the accessibility of Hebrew TTS systems, benefitting applications like screen readers for the visually impaired and voice assistant technologies on resource-constrained devices.
limitations: The performance relies heavily on the underlying diacritization model, which may output inaccuracies affecting transcription quality.

new_terms.grapheme-to-phoneme conversion (G2P): **Grapheme-to-Phoneme conversion (G2P)** refers to the process of converting written text (graphemes) into their corresponding phonetic representations (phonemes) to aid in speech synthesis.
new_terms.International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA): **International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)** is an alphabet used by linguists to accurately represent the sounds of spoken languages.

open_sourcing: The code, data, and models have been released at https://phonikud.github.io
